title: Introduction to the BayesLinearKinematics package
text: BayesLinearKinematics package provides tools performing Bayes linear analysis. involves representing uncertain beliefs quantities using expectation covariance, updating beliefs based observed data uncertain information (kinematics). vignette demonstrates core workflow: defining prior beliefs, structuring observed data, performing adjustments, evaluating result. Note vignette created using R version R version 4.5.1 (2025-06-13) BayesLinearKinematics package version 0.2.12.

title: Introduction to the BayesLinearKinematics package
text: foundation Bayes linear analysis specifying prior beliefs variables interest. done using bl class, stores expectations covariances. Let’s define prior beliefs three variables, xx, yy zz. expect 1, 2 3 respectively. also specify covariance structure. Essentially, , encoding: $$ \begin{align*} \text{E}\pmatrix{x\\y\\z} &= \pmatrix{1 \\ 2 \\ 3} \\ \text{Cov}\pmatrix{x\\y\\z} &= \pmatrix{1.0 & 0.5 & 0.2 \\ 0.5 & 1.0 & 0.5 \\ 0.2 & 0.5 & 1.0} \end{align*} $$ print method gives clean overview. can also visualise covariance matrix using plot method defined bl class: Plot prior covariance matrix. plot shows strength sign prior covariances variables. Red indicates positive covariance, blue negative (though none ), intensity relates magnitude. diagonal elements represent variances.
code: # Define prior beliefs using the bl() constructor bl_prior <- bl(   name = "Prior Beliefs", # A descriptive name for this belief set   varnames = c("x", "y", "z"), # Names of the variables   expectation = c(1, 2, 3), # Prior expected values E[x], E[y], E[z]   covariance = matrix(     c(       1.0, 0.5, 0.2, # Covariance matrix:       0.5, 1.0, 0.5, #   [Var(x) Cov(y,x) Cov(z,x)]       0.2, 0.5, 1.0     ), # [Cov(x,y) Var(y) Cov(z,y)]     nrow = 3, ncol = 3   ) # [Cov(x,z) Cov(y,z) Var(z)] )  # Print the object - uses the custom print method defined for the 'bl' class # The 'digits' argument controls the rounding in the output print(bl_prior, digits = 2) #> Prior Beliefs  #>  #> Expectation: #>     #> x 1 #> y 2 #> z 3 #>  #> Covariance: #>  #>     x   y   z #> x 1.0 0.5 0.2 #> y 0.5 1.0 0.5 #> z 0.2 0.5 1.0 # Plot the covariance matrix using the S4 plot method for 'bl' objects # This method should handle the visualization details internally. plot(bl_prior)

title: Introduction to the BayesLinearKinematics package
text: Suppose observe values variables. represent using bl_data class. Let’s say observed xx 1.1 yy 2.1. ease exposition, denote two observed variables DD (data).
code: # Define observed data using the bl_data() constructor observed_data <- bl_data(   name = "Observations", # A descriptive name for the data   varnames = c("x", "y"), # Names of the observed variables   values = c(1.1, 2.1) ) # The observed values  # Print the data object - uses the custom print method for 'bl_data' print(observed_data) #> Observations  #> Observed values: #>       #> x 1.1 #> y 2.1

title: Introduction to the BayesLinearKinematics package
text: core operation updating prior beliefs (bl_prior) using observed_data. bl_adjust function performs Bayes linear adjustment according standard formulae: $$ \begin{align*} \text{E}_D\pmatrix{x\\y\\z} &= \text{E}\pmatrix{x\\y\\z} + \text{Cov}\left[\pmatrix{x\\y\\z} ,\pmatrix{x\\y}\right]\cdot \text{Cov}\pmatrix{x\\y}^{-1} \cdot \left[D - \text{E}\pmatrix{x\\y}\right]\\ \text{Cov}_D\pmatrix{x\\y\\z} &= \text{Cov}\pmatrix{x\\y\\z} - \text{Cov}\left[\pmatrix{x\\y\\z} ,\pmatrix{x\\y}\right]\cdot \text{Cov}\pmatrix{x\\y}^{-1} \cdot \text{Cov}\left[\pmatrix{x\\y\\z} ,\pmatrix{x\\y}\right]^T. \end{align*} $$ Notice expectations xx, yy zz changed prior values (1, 2, 3) based observations. covariance matrix also updated, reflecting reduced uncertainty (variances diagonal generally smaller). Let’s plot adjusted covariance: Plot covariance matrix adjustment data. Comparing plot prior covariance plot, can see changes, particularly reduction variance (diagonal elements) potentially changes -diagonal covariances, reflecting information gained data.
code: # Perform the adjustment using the prior beliefs and the observed data # x: The 'bl' object containing prior beliefs to be adjusted. # y: The 'bl_data' object containing the observations to adjust by. bl_adjusted_data <- bl_adjust(x = bl_prior, y = observed_data)  # Print the adjusted beliefs. Note the name is automatically generated. # Using more digits to see the effect of the adjustment. print(bl_adjusted_data, digits = 3) #> Prior Beliefs_adj_Observations  #>  #> Expectation: #>         #> x 1.100 #> y 2.100 #> z 3.047 #>  #> Covariance: #>  #>   x y     z #> x 0 0 0.000 #> y 0 0 0.000 #> z 0 0 0.747 # Plot the adjusted covariance matrix plot(bl_adjusted_data)

title: Introduction to the BayesLinearKinematics package
text: bl_adjust function can also update one set beliefs (bl object, x) based another set related beliefs (bl object, y). sometimes referred Bayes linear kinematics. uses similar formulae incorporates uncertainty second belief object (y). Let’s define second belief structure, perhaps representing information yy zz another source (e.g., different sensor expert opinion). Now, adjust original bl_prior using bl_info. adjustment combines information sources.  adjustment incorporates information bl_info prior beliefs, updating expectations covariances according Bayes linear rules combining uncertain information.
code: # Define a second set of beliefs (e.g., from another expert or model) bl_info <- bl(   name = "Sensor Info",   varnames = c("y", "z"), # Variables covered by this info   expectation = c(2.2, 2.8), # Expectations from this source   covariance = matrix(c(     0.5, 0.1, # Covariance structure from this source     0.1, 0.6   ), nrow = 2, ncol = 2) )  print(bl_info, digits = 2) #> Sensor Info  #>  #> Expectation: #>       #> y 2.2 #> z 2.8 #>  #> Covariance: #>  #>     y   z #> y 0.5 0.1 #> z 0.1 0.6 # Perform kinematic adjustment # x: The 'bl' object containing prior beliefs to be adjusted. # y: The 'bl' object containing the other beliefs to adjust by. bl_adjusted_kinematics <- bl_adjust(x = bl_prior, y = bl_info)  # Print the result of the kinematic adjustment print(bl_adjusted_kinematics, digits = 3) #> Prior Beliefs_adj_Sensor Info  #>  #> Expectation: #>        #> x 1.12 #> y 2.20 #> z 2.80 #>  #> Covariance: #>  #>       x    y     z #> x 0.884 0.26 0.013 #> y 0.260 0.50 0.100 #> z 0.013 0.10 0.600  # Plot the resulting covariance after kinematic adjustment plot(bl_adjusted_kinematics)

title: Introduction to the BayesLinearKinematics package
text: much uncertainty reduced adjustment? bl_resolution function calculates , comparing prior variance adjusted variance variable: Resolution = 1 - Var_adjusted / Var_prior. applies comparing prior bl object (x) adjusted bl object (y). Let’s calculate resolution achieved data adjustment performed earlier: resolution close 1 means variance variable greatly reduced adjustment, value close 0 means adjustment little impact variance. , xx yy (observed variables) higher resolution, indicating variance decreased significantly. zz also resolution, reflecting information gained indirectly covariance xx yy. can also calculate resolution resulting kinematic adjustment: shows variance reduction achieved combining bl_prior bl_info.
code: # Calculate the resolution comparing the prior to the data-adjusted beliefs # x: The 'bl' object representing prior beliefs. # y: The 'bl' object representing adjusted beliefs. resolution_values_data <- bl_resolution(x = bl_prior, y = bl_adjusted_data)  # Print the resolutions, rounded for clarity print(round(resolution_values_data, 3)) #>     x     y     z  #> 1.000 1.000 0.253 # Calculate the resolution comparing the prior to the  # kinematically-adjusted beliefs resolution_values_kinematics <- bl_resolution(x = bl_prior,                                               y = bl_adjusted_kinematics)  # Print the resolutions print(round(resolution_values_kinematics, 3)) #>     x     y     z  #> 0.116 0.500 0.400

title: Hellinger distances between belief specifications
text: Bayes linear analysis, represent beliefs using expectations covariances. Sometimes, want quantify “different” two belief specifications . Hellinger distance metric used measure similarity two probability distributions. bl object stores first two moments (expectation covariance), can calculate Hellinger distance multivariate normal distributions share moments. provides useful measure discrepancy two belief specifications encapsulated bl objects. squared Hellinger distance H2(P,Q)H^2(P, Q) ranges 0 1 0 indicates distributions (thus expectations covariances) identical 1 indicates maximal difference. vignette demonstrates use hellinger_squared() function BayesLinearKinematics package calculate distance.

what: Defining the Squared Hellinger Distance (Normal Case)
title: Hellinger distances between belief specifications
text: hellinger_squared() function calculates distance two bl objects x y assuming represent multivariate normal distributions PP QQ respectively means μ1,μ2\mu_1, \mu_2 (x@expectation, y@expectation) covariance matrices Σ1,Σ2\Sigma_1, \Sigma_2 (x@covariance, y@covariance). Univariate Case: bl objects represent beliefs single variable (P=N(μ1,σ12)P = N(\mu_1, \sigma_1^2), Q=N(μ2,σ22)Q = N(\mu_2, \sigma_2^2)), squared Hellinger distance : H2(P,Q)=1−2σ1σ2σ12+σ22exp(−14(μ1−μ2)2σ12+σ22)H^2(P, Q) = 1 - \sqrt{\frac{2 \sigma_1 \sigma_2}{\sigma_1^2 + \sigma_2^2}} \exp\left(-\frac{1}{4} \frac{(\mu_1 - \mu_2)^2}{\sigma_1^2 + \sigma_2^2}\right) Multivariate Case: bl objects represent beliefs multiple variables (P=N(μ1,Σ1)P = N(\mu_1, \Sigma_1), Q=N(μ2,Σ2)Q = N(\mu_2, \Sigma_2)), squared Hellinger distance : H2(P,Q)=1−det(Σ1)1/4det(Σ2)1/4det(Σ1+Σ22)1/2exp(−18(μ1−μ2)T(Σ1+Σ22)−1(μ1−μ2))H^2(P, Q) = 1 - \frac{\det(\Sigma_1)^{1/4} \det(\Sigma_2)^{1/4}}{\det\left(\frac{\Sigma_1 + \Sigma_2}{2}\right)^{1/2}} \exp\left(-\frac{1}{8} (\mu_1 - \mu_2)^T \left(\frac{\Sigma_1 + \Sigma_2}{2}\right)^{-1} (\mu_1 - \mu_2)\right) det(⋅)\det(\cdot) denotes determinant matrix (⋅)−1(\cdot)^{-1} denotes matrix inverse (generalised inverse ginv used function numerical stability).

what: Calculating Distance Between Two Belief Specifications
title: Hellinger distances between belief specifications
text: Let’s define two different belief specifications set variables xx, yy zz. can use hellinger_squared() quantify much beliefs differ. First, define belief_A perhaps representing initial assessment.  Now, define belief_B representing alternative assessment perhaps different expert model.  Now, calculate squared Hellinger distance belief_A belief_B. resulting value (likely small non-zero) quantifies difference two belief specifications normality assumption. value closer 0 indicates higher similarity. Let’s also quickly check univariate case.
code: # Define first belief specification belief_A <- bl(   name = "Belief A",   varnames = c("x", "y", "z"),   expectation = c(1, 2, 3),   covariance = matrix(     c(       1.0, 0.5, 0.2,       0.5, 1.0, 0.5,       0.2, 0.5, 1.0     ),     nrow = 3, ncol = 3   ) )  belief_A #> Belief A  #>  #> Expectation: #>     #> x 1 #> y 2 #> z 3 #>  #> Covariance: #>  #>     x   y   z #> x 1.0 0.5 0.2 #> y 0.5 1.0 0.5 #> z 0.2 0.5 1.0 plot(belief_A) # Define second belief specification (different expectation and covariance) belief_B <- bl(   name = "Belief B",   varnames = c("x", "y", "z"),   expectation = c(1.2, 2.1, 2.9), # Slightly different means   covariance = matrix(     c(       1.1, 0.4, 0.3, # Slightly different covariance       0.4, 0.9, 0.6,       0.3, 0.6, 1.2     ),     nrow = 3, ncol = 3   ) )  belief_B #> Belief B  #>  #> Expectation: #>       #> x 1.2 #> y 2.1 #> z 2.9 #>  #> Covariance: #>  #>     x   y   z #> x 1.1 0.4 0.3 #> y 0.4 0.9 0.6 #> z 0.3 0.6 1.2 plot(belief_B) # Calculate the squared Hellinger distance # x: The first 'bl' object. # y: The second 'bl' object. dist_A_B <- hellinger_squared(x = belief_A, y = belief_B)  # Print the result cat(paste(   "Squared Hellinger distance between Belief A and Belief B:",   round(dist_A_B, 4) )) #> Squared Hellinger distance between Belief A and Belief B: 0.0182 # Univariate beliefs belief_X1 <- bl(name = "X1", varnames = "x",                 expectation = 1, covariance = matrix(1)) belief_X2 <- bl(name = "X2", varnames = "x",                 expectation = 1.5, covariance = matrix(1.2))  dist_X1_X2 <- hellinger_squared(belief_X1, belief_X2)  cat(paste(   "Squared Hellinger distance between Belief X1 and Belief X2:",   round(dist_X1_X2, 4) )) #> Squared Hellinger distance between Belief X1 and Belief X2: 0.03  # Check distance to self (should be 0) dist_X1_X1 <- hellinger_squared(belief_X1, belief_X1) cat(paste(   "\nSquared Hellinger distance between Belief X1 and itself:",   round(dist_X1_X1, 4) )) #>  #> Squared Hellinger distance between Belief X1 and itself: 0

what: Measuring the Impact of Kinematic Adjustment
title: Hellinger distances between belief specifications
text: Hellinger distance can also used measure much belief specification changes undergoing Bayes linear adjustment (kinematics). can calculate distance prior beliefs adjusted beliefs. Let’s reuse prior beliefs (bl_prior) kinematic information (bl_info) introductory vignette examples. Now, calculate squared Hellinger distance prior belief (bl_prior) belief state adjustment (bl_adjusted_kinematics). Note bl_adjust might adjust subset variables bl_info covers fewer variables bl_prior. hellinger_squared requires inputs cover set variables. calculate distance variables common stages adjustment .e. variables present bl_adjusted_kinematics. specific case, bl_adjust preserves variables bl_prior can compare directly.   distance quantifies magnitude belief change induced kinematic update bl_info. larger value implies kinematic information caused greater shift belief state (mean /covariance structure) normality assumption.
code: # Define prior beliefs (same as intro vignette) bl_prior <- bl(   name = "Prior Beliefs",   varnames = c("x", "y", "z"),   expectation = c(1, 2, 3),   covariance = matrix(     c(       1.0, 0.5, 0.2,       0.5, 1.0, 0.5,       0.2, 0.5, 1.0     ),     nrow = 3, ncol = 3   ) )  # Define kinematic information (same as intro vignette) bl_info <- bl(   name = "Info",   varnames = c("y", "z"),   expectation = c(2.2, 2.8),   covariance = matrix(c(     0.5, 0.1,     0.1, 0.6   ), nrow = 2, ncol = 2) )  # Perform the kinematic adjustment bl_adjusted_kinematics <- bl_adjust(x = bl_prior, y = bl_info)  # Quick look at the prior and adjusted beliefs bl_prior #> Prior Beliefs  #>  #> Expectation: #>     #> x 1 #> y 2 #> z 3 #>  #> Covariance: #>  #>     x   y   z #> x 1.0 0.5 0.2 #> y 0.5 1.0 0.5 #> z 0.2 0.5 1.0 bl_adjusted_kinematics #> Prior Beliefs_adj_Info  #>  #> Expectation: #>        #> x 1.12 #> y 2.20 #> z 2.80 #>  #> Covariance: #>  #>      x    y    z #> x 0.88 0.26 0.01 #> y 0.26 0.50 0.10 #> z 0.01 0.10 0.60 # Plot prior covariance plot(bl_prior) # Plot adjusted covariance plot(bl_adjusted_kinematics) # Calculate squared Hellinger distance between prior and adjusted beliefs dist_kinematic <- hellinger_squared(x = bl_prior,                                     y = bl_adjusted_kinematics)  # Print the result cat(paste(   "\nSquared Hellinger distance between Prior and Adjusted (Kinematic):",   round(dist_kinematic, 4) )) #>  #> Squared Hellinger distance between Prior and Adjusted (Kinematic): 0.0637

title: Hellinger distances between belief specifications
text: hellinger_squared function includes several checks: ensures inputs (x y) bl objects. verifies bl objects contain exact set variable names (varnames). internally reorders second object (y) match variable order first object (x) using bl_subset performing calculations ensuring alignment. conditions met, function stop return informative error message.

title: Hellinger distances between belief specifications
text: vignette demonstrated use hellinger_squared() function compute measure distance two belief specifications (bl objects) based corresponding multivariate normal distributions. reviewed formulae used univariate multivariate cases. calculated distance two distinct bl objects (belief_A belief_B). calculated distance prior belief (bl_prior) state kinematic update (bl_adjusted_kinematics) quantify impact adjustment. squared Hellinger distance provides value 0 1 offering standardised way compare belief structures measure effect belief updates within BayesLinearKinematics framework assuming normality based first two moments.

code: # Prior Beliefs bl_prior <- bl(   name = "Prior State",   varnames = c("P1", "P2", "P3"),   expectation = c(10, 20, 30),   covariance = matrix(c(     4, 1, 0.5,     1, 5, 1,     0.5, 1, 6   ), 3, 3) )  # Adjusted Beliefs (after some adjustment process) bl_adjusted <- bl(   name = "Adjusted State",   varnames = c("P1", "P2", "P3"),   expectation = c(11, 20.5, 29),   covariance = matrix(c(     2, 0.5, 0.2,     0.5, 2.5, 0.5,     0.2, 0.5, 3   ), 3, 3) )  # Calculate resolution resolutions <- bl_resolution(bl_prior, bl_adjusted) print(resolutions) #>  P1  P2  P3  #> 0.5 0.5 0.5  # Should output something like: # P1  P2  P3 # 0.5 0.5 0.5  # Example with potential issues (e.g., zero prior variance - may warn/error) bl_prior_zero_var <- bl(   name = "Prior with Zero Var",   varnames = "Z", expectation = 0, covariance = 0 ) bl_adjusted_zero_var <- bl(   name = "Adjusted with Zero Var",   varnames = "Z", expectation = 1, covariance = 0.1 ) # try(bl_resolution(bl_prior_zero_var, bl_adjusted_zero_var))
